section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This hands-on section provides practical experience with Python's core data structures through interactive coding exercises. Students will build foundational skills in variable manipulation, type conversion, and data validation while solving real-world scenarios.
learning_objectives: Declare variables following Python naming conventions
Identify and differentiate between string, integer, float, and boolean data types
Convert between data types using built-in functions
Determine mutability characteristics of different data structures
Validate variable types during program execution

lessons.lesson_title: Variable Declaration and Basic Type Identification
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will correctly declare variables with valid names and identify string, integer, and float data types using type()
key_topics: Assigning string values with single/double quotes
Using type() for runtime type checking

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for your first_name (string), birth_year (integer), and height_meters (float). Print each variable with its data type using type().

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will convert numeric inputs to strings and manipulate text using concatenation and string methods
key_topics: Common string methods: upper(), lower(), strip()

exercises.exercise_instructions: Convert price (9.99) and quantity (5) to strings. Create a product label showing 'Total: $49.95' using string concatenation and currency formatting.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will perform arithmetic operations on numeric types and safely convert between integers and floats
key_topics: Precision handling in floating point operations

exercises.exercise_instructions: Convert 150 USD to Euros using an exchange rate of 0.93. Calculate and print the result as a float rounded to two decimal places, then convert to integer cents.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will evaluate boolean expressions and demonstrate understanding of mutable vs immutable types

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a list [1,2,3] and a tuple (1,2,3). Print their memory IDs, attempt to change the first element, and explain the outcome based on mutability.
